lei_do_inquilinato.name: Lei do Inquilinato (Lei nº 8.245/91)
lei_do_inquilinato.description: The main law governing residential and commercial rentals in Brazil.
key_provisions: Defines rights and obligations of landlords and tenants

codigo_civil.name: Código Civil Brasileiro (Lei nº 10.406/2002)
codigo_civil.description: The Brazilian Civil Code contains general contract provisions applicable to rental agreements.
key_provisions: Articles 565-578 specifically address leasing (locação de coisas)
Establishes general principles for contracts that apply to leases

codigo_do_consumidor.name: Código de Defesa do Consumidor (Lei nº 8.078/90)
codigo_do_consumidor.description: The Consumer Protection Code may apply to rental relationships in certain circumstances.

basic_rights: Right to a habitable dwelling in good condition
Right to peaceful enjoyment of the property
Right to have the security deposit returned at the end of the lease
Right to have maintenance and necessary repairs carried out by the landlord

rent_adjustments.description: Rent can typically only be adjusted annually based on an inflation index specified in the contract.
rent_adjustments.restrictions: Arbitrary increases outside of the contractual provisions are prohibited.

by_tenant.description: A tenant can terminate a fixed-term lease before its end by paying a proportional fine.
by_tenant.penalties: If terminating before the end of a fixed-term contract, the tenant may have to pay a penalty, which is typically proportional to the remaining time.

security_deposits.description: Brazilian law limits security deposits and sets rules for their return.
security_deposits.limit: Typically, the security deposit should not exceed three months of rent.
security_deposits.return_period: The deposit should be returned within 30 days after the end of the lease, minus any legitimate deductions.

main_duties: Deliver the property in a habitable condition
Maintain the structural integrity of the building
Make necessary repairs (unless otherwise agreed in the contract)
Ensure peaceful use of the property
Pay property taxes (IPTU) and building fees (condomínio) unless otherwise agreed

repairs.description: Landlords are responsible for structural repairs and maintenance of essential systems.
repairs.exceptions: The contract may specify certain maintenance responsibilities to be borne by the tenant.

illegal_practices: Cutting off utilities to force eviction
Removing the tenant's belongings without a court order

fixed_term.description: Contract with a specified duration, typically 30 months for residential properties.
fixed_term.minimum_duration: No legally mandated minimum, but 30 months is common to avoid automatic conversion to indefinite term.
fixed_term.renewal: If the tenant stays beyond the end date with the landlord's consent, the contract converts to indefinite term.

indefinite_term.description: Contract without a specified end date, continuing until either party gives notice.
indefinite_term.termination: Either party can terminate with 30 days notice.

for_tenants: Proof of income (typically 3x the monthly rent)

guarantees.description: Brazilian law allows several types of guarantees to secure rental payment.

grounds: Need of the property by the owner for personal use
Demolition or substantial renovation of the property

procedure.description: Eviction in Brazil typically requires a court order and follows a judicial process.
steps: Enforcement of the order by a court official
procedure.timeline: The process can take from a few months to over a year, depending on the case complexity and local court backlog.

non_payment.description: Eviction for non-payment is one of the most common cases.
non_payment.purge_period: The tenant typically has 15 days to pay the debt and avoid eviction after being notified.

repair_issues.description: Disputes over who is responsible for repairs are common.
repair_issues.resolution: The rental contract and the Lei do Inquilinato determine responsibility. Generally, structural repairs are the landlord's responsibility while day-to-day maintenance falls to the tenant.

rent_increases.description: Disputes often arise over the amount or frequency of rent increases.
rent_increases.resolution: Rent can only be increased according to the contract terms, typically annually based on an inflation index.

security_deposit.description: Disputes about the return of security deposits are common.
security_deposit.resolution: The landlord must justify any deductions from the deposit with evidence of damages beyond normal wear and tear.

early_termination.description: Disagreements about penalties for early termination of contracts.
early_termination.resolution: The Lei do Inquilinato sets parameters for proportional fines, typically related to the remaining contract period.
